claim: Most middle class families have butlers.

supporting.text: Butlers are traditionally associated with wealthy households, not middle-class families.

attacks.text: Butlers are traditionally associated with wealthy households, not middle-class families.
Modern middle-class households increasingly hire part-time butlers or domestic assistants due to rising disposable income.
The term 'butler' is often misapplied to general domestic help, diluting its traditional association with wealth.
Statistical data shows less than 5% of middle-class households employ dedicated butlers globally.
Regional exceptions exist where butlers are culturally normalized for middle-class families (e.g., some Asian countries).

supporting.text: The cost of employing a butler is typically beyond the financial means of middle-class families.

attacks.text: The cost of employing a butler is typically beyond the financial means of middle-class families.
Some middle-class families may have inherited wealth or additional income sources, allowing them to afford a butler.
Inherited wealth or additional income sources are statistically rare among middle-class families.
In certain countries or cultures, domestic help like butlers is more affordable and common even for middle-class families.
Even in such countries, 'butlers' in middle-class households are often part-time or multi-role domestic workers, not traditional butlers.

supporting.text: Modern middle-class households generally rely on automation and occasional domestic help rather than full-time butlers.

attacks.text: Modern middle-class households generally rely on automation and occasional domestic help rather than full-time butlers.
Some affluent middle-class families in certain regions still employ full-time butlers as a status symbol.
The number of families employing full-time butlers is statistically negligible compared to the total middle-class population.
Historical data shows that butler employment was never common in middle-class households, even in the past.
Modern middle-class lifestyles prioritize cost-efficiency, making butler employment economically impractical.

supporting.text: Statistical data on household employment does not support the claim that butlers are common in middle-class homes.

attacks.text: Statistical data on household employment does not support the claim that butlers are common in middle-class homes.
Historical data shows that butlers were more common in upper-class households, not middle-class ones.
Modern definitions of middle-class may include households with higher disposable income, potentially allowing for domestic staff.
Even with higher disposable income, cultural shifts have reduced the demand for traditional butler services in middle-class households.

supporting.text: Cultural norms in most countries do not include butlers as a standard feature of middle-class family life.

attacks.text: Cultural norms in most countries do not include butlers as a standard feature of middle-class family life.
Historical data shows that butlers were traditionally employed only by wealthy families, not the middle class.
In some cultures, domestic help is more common and affordable, blurring the line between middle class and upper class.
Even in cultures with affordable domestic help, butlers specifically remain a luxury service typically beyond middle-class means.
Modern middle-class families often outsource domestic tasks to cleaning services rather than employing full-time butlers.
Some high-income middle-class families in urban areas might employ butlers as a status symbol.
